thought_pattern: Ugh, what's even the point? Nothing ever changes anyway, so why bother trying? The more I think about it, the more exhausted I feel.
pattern_description: Persistent hopelessness drains motivation, creating mental shutdown.
source_question: What goes through your head when you try to muster motivation?

thought_pattern: What's the point? It's all just a waste of time anyway. Nothing ever changes, no matter how hard I try or what I do - my mind is already made up, it's hopeless from the start.
pattern_description: Persistent hopelessness drains motivation, creating mental shutdown.
source_question: What goes through your mind when someone suggests things could get better?

thought_pattern: What's the point? Even if I were to try, what's the likelihood that anything would actually change? It's all just a cycle of disappointment and heartache.
pattern_description: Persistent hopelessness drains motivation, creating mental shutdown.
source_question: How exhausting is it to your mind to consider that help might work?

thought_pattern:
What's the point? Recovery seems like a myth created to torture me. Nothing ever changes; why should this time be any different?

(Note: The internal monologue is intentionally written in short, fragmented sentences to reflect the disjointed and chaotic nature of hopelessness-driven cognitive exhaustion.)
pattern_description: Persistent hopelessness drains motivation, creating mental shutdown.
source_question: What occurs mentally when you attempt to believe recovery is achievable?

thought_pattern: Why even bother? It's all just a pointless effort anyway. Every small step feels like climbing an endless mountain - why exhaust myself trying?
pattern_description: Persistent hopelessness drains motivation, creating mental shutdown.
source_question: How depleted do you feel when thinking about making positive changes?

thought_pattern:
What's even the point? Nothing ever changes anyway... I'm just stuck in this rut, no matter how hard I try or pretend to. Why bother putting any effort into making things better when it'll all just be for nothing in the end?

(Note: These thoughts are intended to be a realistic representation of someone experiencing cognitive exhaustion driven by hopelessness. They may not be immediately uplifting or inspiring, but rather an honest reflection of the mental state.)
pattern_description: Persistent hopelessness drains motivation, creating mental shutdown.
source_question: How drained do you feel when considering making any effort to change?

thought_pattern: What's the point anyway? It feels like no matter what I do, nothing will change or get better. Even thinking about trying to find hope feels like a waste of energy, because it'll only lead to disappointment again.
pattern_description: Persistent hopelessness drains motivation, creating mental shutdown.
source_question: What's it like to think about the possibility of hope when you feel none?

thought_pattern:
What happens mentally when you attempt to generate hope?

"I'm just wasting my time, anything I think of feels pointless anyway. Why bother? Nothing ever changes. The same old feelings and emotions will just come back to haunt me once more."
pattern_description: Persistent hopelessness drains motivation, creating mental shutdown.
source_question: What happens mentally when you attempt to generate hope?

thought_pattern: What's the point of even trying? Nothing ever changes anyway, so why waste my energy on hope. It's not like anything will get better â€“ what's the use of pretending otherwise?

source_question: How much mental energy do you have left for believing things will improve?

thought_pattern: What's even the point of trying anymore? Nothing ever changes, and I'm just exhausting myself for no reason.
pattern_description: Persistent hopelessness drains motivation, creating mental shutdown.
source_question: How much does the futility of everything drain your thinking capacity?

thought_pattern: What's the point of even trying? What's the use in dreaming up some fantasy future when everything always ends up feeling like a cruel joke anyway?
pattern_description: Persistent hopelessness drains motivation, creating mental shutdown.
source_question: What happens in your mind when you try to envision a better future?

thought_pattern: I'm just going through the motions, pretending like anything will change. What's the point of even trying? Nothing ever gets better.
pattern_description: Persistent hopelessness drains motivation, creating mental shutdown.
source_question: What's it like cognitively when you try to imagine improvement is possible?

thought_pattern: Ugh, what's even the point? Nothing ever changes anyway, so why bother trying? It's like my brain is stuck on repeat, playing the same old negative tapestry, and it exhausts me just thinking about making any effort.
pattern_description: Persistent hopelessness drains motivation, creating mental shutdown.
source_question: How difficult has it become to imagine any positive changes in your future?

thought_pattern: Ugh, why even try? It's all just a waste of energy anyway... Every problem feels like this never-ending mountain to climb, and the thought of putting one foot in front of the other is exhausting me.
pattern_description: Persistent hopelessness drains motivation, creating mental shutdown.
source_question: How tired does it make you to think about fighting your problems anymore?

thought_pattern: Ugh, what's even the point of trying? The thought of tomorrow just exhausts me. I'm already so drained from yesterday's struggles and today's disappointments, there's no way I can muster up any energy to think about what's next.
pattern_description: Persistent hopelessness drains motivation, creating mental shutdown.
source_question: What happens to your energy when you try to think about tomorrow?

thought_pattern: I'm just so done with trying. What's the point anyway? It's not like anything ever changes or improves... My energy is spent, and even thinking about it exhausts me further.
pattern_description: Persistent hopelessness drains motivation, creating mental shutdown.
source_question: How mentally fatigued do you become when considering that things matter?

thought_pattern: Why bother trying? Every attempt feels like an uphill battle against a crushing weight of impossibility. What's even the point when everything just seems to end in futility, anyway?
pattern_description: Persistent hopelessness drains motivation, creating mental shutdown.
source_question: How exhausting is it to contemplate trying to improve things?

thought_pattern: What's the point? I'm just going to fail again anyway, so why even try?
pattern_description: Persistent hopelessness drains motivation, creating mental shutdown.
source_question: What happens to your thought processes when you contemplate trying again?

thought_pattern: What a never-ending cycle of despair. Every moment feels like an eternity, weighing me down with the certainty that nothing will ever change. How am I supposed to muster the energy to face another day when every ounce of hope has been drained from me?
pattern_description: Persistent hopelessness drains motivation, creating mental shutdown.
source_question: How exhausted do you feel when contemplating continued existence?

thought_pattern:
What's my response when people suggest reasons for optimism? Ugh, they just don't get it. 

Here are my realistic internal monologue thoughts:

"I keep wondering if anyone really understands how suffocating hopelessness feels. My mind won't stop replaying all the things that have gone wrong, and every attempt to find a silver lining only makes me feel more anxious."

or

"Why do people think I'm just being pessimistic when I share my concerns? Can't they see that these 'positive vibes' only make me feel like I'm stuck in some kind of never-ending nightmare?"

Please note that these thoughts might not be the most articulate or clear, as the aim is to capture the authentic, unfiltered mental experience.
pattern_description: Persistent hopelessness drains motivation, creating mental shutdown.
source_question: What's your mental response when people suggest reasons for optimism?
